Fig. 1 X-ray diffraction patterns (a) and FT-IR spectra (b) of the zirconium-tin phosphate catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM images of (a) ZrP, (b) Zr0.6Sn0.4P, (c) Zr0.5Sn0.5P, (d) Zr0.4Sn0.6P and (e) SnP. (f) HAADF-STEM image and (g-j) corresponding EDS elemental mappings of Zr0.6Sn0.4P. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XPS profiles of the zirconium-tin phosphate catalysts: (a) survey scan, (b) Zr 3d, (c) Sn 3d and (d) P2p. Zirconium-tin phosphate as an efficient catalyst for renewable p-xylene synthesis from biobased 2,5-dimethylfuran and ethylene Chengming Wu Data curation Investigation Writing – original draft a b Hongbo Chen Data curation a Jifan Li Writing – review & editing a Chun-Ling Liu Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Wen-Sheng Dong Data curation Supervision Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU), MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi’an 710062, China Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU), MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University Xi’an 710062 China Key Laboratory of Applied Surface and Colloid Chemistry (SNNU), MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi’an 710062, China b School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Hanjiang Normal University, Shiyan 442000, China School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Hanjiang Normal University Shiyan 442000 China School of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Hanjiang Normal University, Shiyan 442000, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Efficient production of renewable p-xylene (PX) from bio-based 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) and ethylene is challenging. Herein, novel nanoflake-like zirconium-tin phosphate catalysts were synthesized, and their catalytic performance was evaluated in the conversion of DMF and ethylene to PX. The DMF conversion, PX selectivity and PX yield reached up to 99%, 95.2% and 94.2%, respectively over Zr0.6Sn0.4P under relatively mild conditions. The PX productivity was 61.1 mmolPX·gcat −1·h−1, which is better than that of previously reported catalysts. By combining characterization with activity test, it was found that enhanced DMF and ethylene adsorption is beneficial to promoting the reaction between DMF and ethylene. Precise regulation of acid sites is crucial for inhibiting the occurrence of side reactions and improving the selectivity of PX. The kinetic analysis revealed that Zr0.6Sn0.4P had a relatively low apparent activation energy (39 kJ·mol−1) for this reaction than previously reported catalysts. In addition, the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst exhibited an excellent reusability. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Biomass 2,5-Dimethylfuran Zirconium-tin phosphate Reaction mechanism p-Xylene Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction p-Xylene (PX), as an important raw material for the preparation of terephthalic acid (PTA) and polyethylene terephthalate (PET), has received great attention because of its increasing demand (6–8% per year) [1,2]. Currently, PX is mainly produced through the catalytic reforming and cracking of non-renewable petroleum [2]. To alleviate environmental problems and achieve sustainable development, the production of PX and its derivatives from biomass resources instead of traditional fossil feedstocks has great attraction in the areas of renewable biomass conversion and green chemistry [3]. Although significant progress has been made in the production of PX through catalytic conversion of cellulose derivatives (bio-ethanol and bio-isobutanol) or pyrolysis (or reforming) of biomass materials, all of these processes suffer from disadvantages, such as low PX yields (40%), requiring complex multi-step reaction pathways, and more energy consumption for PX separation and purification [4–7]. Recently, the synthesis of renewable PX using bio-based 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) and ethylene as raw materials has attained much attention [8,9]. However, the exploitation of highly efficient solid acid catalysts for the preparation of PX from DMF and ethylene with desired yields is a great challenge because of the tandem reaction including Diels-Alder reaction and dehydration reaction as well as inevitable side reactions to form byproducts and undetectable oligomers ( Scheme 1) [10–14]. Especially for solid acid catalysts with high acid strength, side reactions such as PX alkylation, DMF hydrolysis and subsequent condensation, are prone to occur, which greatly reduces the PX selectivity, and accelerates the deactivation of the catalysts because of the deposition of oligomers on the surface. So far, various solid acid catalysts have been designed and applied to synthesize PX from DMF and ethylene [15–25]. For example, Kim et al. [15] reported that a PX yield of 75.8% was obtained using mesoporous ZSM-5 catalysts under 250 °C for 24 h. Wijaya et al. [16] reported that HPW/SiO2 and HSiW/SiO2 catalysts exhibited a high DMF conversion of 91–94% with a PX selectivity of 82–85%. Yin et al. [18] found that NbOx catalysts with a B/L ratio of 2.9 and large mesopores exhibited good catalytic activity, giving 87.2% DMF conversion and 76.3% PX yield, respectively at 250 °C for 6 h. Zhao et al. [19] prepared dealuminated H-Beta zeolite by treating the aluminum-rich H-Beta with HNO3 aqueous solution, and obtained a DMF conversion of 99% and a PX yield of 97% after reaction at 300 °C for 24 h. Jae et al. [20] found that phosphated TiO2 with abundant weak acid sites was more efficient to catalyze the transformation of DMF and ethylene into PX. Chang et al. [23] achieved 99% DMF conversion and 90.0% PX selectivity on Zr-BEA zeolite catalyst within 24 h at 250 °C. Most recently, Ma et al. [24] reported that a PX yield of 91.1% was obtained over SCM-36 zeolite at 250 °C for 24 h. Although remarkable progress has been achieved in the synthesis of PX from DMF and ethylene, unfortunately, most of these catalysts suffered from issues such as low PX yield or productivity and long reaction time. Therefore, the development of highly efficient solid acid catalysts with well-controlled quantity and strength of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, and large mesoporosity is still urgently needed for synthesizing PX with high yield and productivity. Metal phosphates with large specific surface area, abundant mesopores, appropriate acidity, and good stability exhibit excellent catalytic performance for various biomass related chemical transformations [26–31]. Despite significant efforts in synthesizing highly active metal phosphates with controllable acidity and textural properties, their relatively low surface area and acid site concentration limit their application in the PX synthesis from DMF and ethylene [32]. Recently, Bae et al. [32] prepared a range of mesoporous zirconium phosphate (ZrP) grafted on the high specific area silicas to address the above challenges, a high PX yield (87.1%) was obtained on ZrP1.5-SBA at 250 °C for 24 h. In this work, we prepared a series of high specific area and mesoporous zirconium-tin phosphates using a simple hydrothermal method. By adjusting the doping amount of tin, the acidic properties of the catalysts and adsorption properties for the reactant molecules can be finely regulated. The optimized Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst showed excellent catalytic activity. In the presence of small amount of catalyst (2.5 wt% DMF), the DMF conversion and PX yield were 99% and 94.2% at 260 °C for 12 h, respectively. Furthermore, Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst can be easily regenerated by calcination and exhibited an excellent catalytic stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 2,5-hexanedione (HDO, 97%), 2.5-Dimethylfuran (DMF, 99%), p-xylene (PX, 99%), 1,4-dioxane (99%) and n-decane (99%) were bought from Aladdin (Shanghai, China). SnCl4·5 H2O (99%) was obtained from Macklin (Shanghai, China). NH4H2PO4 (99%), ZrOCl2·8 H2O (99%), AlCl3·6 H2O (97%), CeCl3·7 H2O (99%) and TiCl4 (98%) were provided by Sinopharm (Shanghai, China). Ethylene (99.5%) and nitrogen (99.99%) were supplied by Tenglong Chemical Co., Ltd (Xi'an, China). All the chemicals were used as received. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis The zirconium-tin phosphate catalysts were synthesized via a simple hydrothermal method. In a typical synthesis, 20 mmol mixed ZrOCl2·8 H2O and SnCl4·5 H2O were firstly dissolved in 40 ml deionized water. Then, the above solution was added dropwise to an aqueous solution of NH4H2PO4 (50 mmol in 20 ml deionized water) under vigorous stirring. After 6 h, the resulting sol solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (100 ml), followed by hydrothermal treatment at 100 °C for 24 h. Afterwards, the white precipitate was isolated by centrifuge, washed thoroughly with deionized water and ethanol, and then dried at 100 °C for 12 h. Finally, the power was calcined in static air at 500 °C (4 h) with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. The as-prepared catalysts were denoted as Zr1-x Sn x P (x = 0, 0.4, 0.5, 0.6 and 1). In addition, Zr0.6M0.4P catalysts (M = Al, Ti, Ce) were also prepared using the same procedure with the addition of different metal precursors. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (tube voltage: 40 kV and tube current: 40 mA). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were acquired on a Thermo Fisher Nicolet IS10 spectrometer using the KBr pellet method. The metal contents of the catalysts were measured by the X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (Shimadzu XRF 1800). The textural properties of the catalysts were analyzed using an ASAP 2020 PLUS HD88 surface and porosity analyzer (Micromeritics, USA). The morphology of the catalysts was observed using a JEOL JSM-6010/LA schottky field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) at 1 kV and a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 high-resolution transmission electron microscope (TEM) at 200 kV. High-angel annular dark-file scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and EDS mapping were obtained using an FEI Talos F200X at 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted using a Kratos Axis Ultra electron spectrometer with monochromated Al Kα radiation. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) of the used catalyst was conducted on the TA-Q600SDT Thermogravimetric Analyzer from 30 to 800 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C/min under a 100 ml/min air flow. The quantity and strength of acid sites on the catalysts were determined by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) using an AutoChem 2920 instrument (Micromeritics, American) equipped with a mass spectrometer (MS). The acidity properties of catalysts were identified by pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy on Nicolet IS10 spectrometer under vacuum at 150 °C (Thermo Fisher Scientific, American). The 31P solid-state NMR experiments were recorded on a Bruker Avance III HD 400WB spectrometer, and 31P chemical shifts were referenced using NH4H2PO4 (ADP) as an external reference (0.81 ppm). The adsorption properties of reactants (DMF and ethylene) on the catalysts surface were evaluated on an AutoChem 2920 instrument (equipped with a mass spectrometer) through the temperature-programmed desorption technique (TPD). About 50 mg catalyst was loaded in a quartz reactor and pretreated at 400 °C for 60 min in He. Subsequently, the reactor was cooled to 50 °C and ethylene was introduced for 30 min for C2H4-TPD; in the case of DMF-TPD, DMF vapor was introduced by 25 pulses using a steam generator. Then, the catalyst was purged with He flow for 30 min and then heated to 500 °C in He flow at a ramping rate of 10 °C/min. The temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) of DMF and ethylene on the catalyst surface was also investigated using the same procedure, in which the DMF and ethylene were successively introduced onto the catalyst surface with different order. Finally, the products such as PX, HDO, CH, AP and CP were detected by a mass spectrometer. During the TPSR-DMF-C2H4 process, the DMF was firstly introduced, followed by ethylene. On the contrary, for the TPSR-C2H4-DMF process, the ethylene was firstly introduced, followed by DMF. 2.4 Catalyst tests All reactions were conducted in a 50 ml micro-autoclave reactor (Shanghai Rock Experimental Instrument Co., Ltd). For a typical run, the quantitative catalyst and DMF were loaded into the reactor with n-decane (16.7 g) as the solvent. The reactor was sealed, and the air inside the reactor was replaced with N2, followed by pressurization with 4 MPa ethylene. Afterward, the reaction mixture was heated to the predetermined temperature for the desired time at a stirring rate of 800 rpm. After the reaction, the reactor was quenched in an ice-water bath immediately. The catalyst was removed from the solution by centrifuge, and the liquid sample was analyzed by Agilent GC-7820A gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). All samples were analyzed three times by the gas chromatography, and mean values were quoted as results. Furthermore, to check the reproducibility, some experiments were repeated three times, and the results (DMF conversion and PX selectivity) exhibited high consistency with a relative standard deviation less than 2%. The DMF conversion (X DMF), product selectivity (S i) and PX yield (Y PX) were calculated as follows: (1) X D M F = moles of converted DMF moles of initial DMF × 100 % (2) S i = moles of product i moles of converted DMF × 100 % (3) Y PX = moles of product PX moles of initial DMF × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts The compositions of the zirconium-tin phosphates were measured by XRF, and the results are presented in Table 1. The mole ratio of Zr to Sn is close to the theoretical value, suggesting that tin species were successfully incorporated into the zirconium phosphate. XRD patterns of the zirconium-tin phosphate catalysts ( Fig. 1a) show several broad, weak diffraction peaks, and no peaks from either zirconium or tin phosphate crystals were detected, suggesting that all of the catalysts are amorphous [29,33,34]. FT-IR spectra of the zirconium-tin phosphates are presented in Fig. 1b. Compared with ZrP, a new adsorption peak appears at 603 cm−1 for the zirconium-tin phosphates, which is caused by the vibration of the Sn-O bond [35]. The peak is intensified with the addition of tin, indicating an increase in the amount of Sn-O bonds. In addition, with the addition of tin in the zirconium-tin phosphates, the peak value of asymmetric P-O-M stretching vibration shifts from 1085 cm−1 for ZrP to 1022 cm−1 for Zr0.4Sn0.6P, which could be caused by the high electronegativity of tin [27,36]. The incorporation of tin species in the zirconium phosphate framework enhances the polarity of P-O-M bonds and then reduces the vibration frequency of P-O-M. The enhancement of P-O-M bond polarity contributes to improve the Lewis acid strength of metal species [22,36]. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms results are displayed in Fig. S1. According to IUPAC classification, all the catalysts possess the type IV adsorption isotherm with a H4 type hysteresis loop [37]. The results indicate that the synthesized catalysts are mesoporous material with a layered structure, which can also be verified by the pore size distribution curves (Fig. S1b) and SEM images (Fig. S2). The detailed textural parameters of the catalysts are summarized in Table 1. The specific surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter of the ZrP catalyst is 411 m2/g, 0.70 cm3/g and 7.8 nm, respectively. As the content of Sn in the zirconium-tin phosphates increases, the specific surface area gradually decreases, while the average pore diameter increases slightly from 5.0 nm for Zr0.6Sn0.4P to 5.5 nm for Zr0.4Sn0.6P, which is still lower than that of ZrP. The introduction of tin species has a certain impact on the texture properties of materials, while the zirconium-tin phosphates still have high specific surface area and mesoporous structure, which can greatly facilitate the transport of reactants and products [15–17]. The morphology and microstructure of the zirconium-tin phosphates are displayed in Fig. 2 and Fig. S2. The ZrP is composed of nano-sheets with a thickness of ∼3 nm. As the tin content increases, the zirconium-tin phosphates maintain a nanosheet-like morphology, while the thickness of the sheets gradually increases, which may lead to a decrease in the specific surface area of the materials. The results are consistent with the N2 absorption/desorption analysis data. The elemental mapping of Zr0.6Sn0.4P indicates that all the elements i.e. Zr, Sn, P and O are distributed uniformly in the catalyst (Fig. 2g-j). The surface element composition and chemical state of the zirconium-tin phosphates were investigated by XPS. The survey scan profiles in Fig. 3a further confirm that the zirconium-tin phosphates are composed of Zr, Sn, P and O. As shown in Fig. 3b, the Zr 3d line consists of two peaks attributed to Zr 3d3/2 at ∼186 eV and Zr 3d5/2 at ∼183 eV, which are the characteristics of tetravalent zirconium (Zr4+) [38,39]. For the Sn 3d profile (Fig. 3c), two peaks were found at ∼496 eV for Sn 3d3/2 and ∼487 eV for Sn 3d5/2, indicating that the tin species mainly exist in Sn4+ state in the zirconium-tin phosphate [40,41]. The peak intensity of Sn element increases with the addition of tin, while the peak intensity of Zr element decreases gradually. The binding energies of Zr and Sn in the zirconium-tin phosphates are all higher than those in ZrP and SnP, indicating that the electron density of Zr and Sn species in the zirconium-tin phosphates decreased, which results in stronger Lewis acidity of Zr(IV) and Sn(IV) [29,40]. The binding energy of P in the zirconium-tin phosphates also shifts to higher values (Fig. 3d), indicating an increased number of hydroxyl groups bound to P on the zirconium-tin phosphates surface [27]. The enhanced Lewis acidity and increased hydroxyl groups in zirconium-tin phosphates would lead to an increase in the adsorption capacity for the reactant ethylene and DMF molecules, respectively [11,24,42]. The surface Zr/Sn atomic ratios of the zirconium-tin phosphates obtained from XPS characterization are summarized in Table S1. For the Zr0.6Sn0.4P, Zr0.5Sn0.5P and Zr0.4Sn0.6P, the Zr/Sn atomic ratios are 1.46, 0.97 and 0.64, respectively, which are basically consistent with the XRF data, indicating that the tin species are uniformly dispersed in the materials. More accurate information on the local environment of phosphorus in the ZrP and Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalysts were characterized by the 31P solid-state MAS NMR, and the spectra are shown in Fig. S3. The ZrP and Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalysts exhibit relatively broad resonance peaks, indicating that they are amorphous [38,43], which is accordance with the XRD results. Moreover, the spectra of ZrP and Zr0.6Sn0.4P were deconvoluted, and both show four resonance positions, i.e. (M-O)-PO(OH)2 ( δ 31 P = −10), (M-O)2-PO(OH) ( δ 31 P = −16), (M-O)3-PO ( δ 31 P = −20) and P-O-P ( δ 31 P = −29, M = Zr or Sn) [38,43,44]. The relative amounts of different phosphate species for ZrP and Zr0.6Sn0.4P are shown in Fig. S3 (In parentheses). It can be found that the number of P-O-P species in Zr0.6Sn0.4P is lower than that in ZrP, indicating that the Brønsted acid sites in Zr0.6Sn0.4P should be lower than that in ZrP, as previous studies have confirmed that the more P-O-P species in zirconium phosphate, the more Brønsted acid sites in the catalysts [38,45]. The results suggest that the incorporation of tin changes the local environment of phosphorus, and then modulates the acidity of the catalysts. The acidic properties of the zirconium-tin phosphate were evaluated using NH3-TPD. As presented in Fig. 4a-b, a broad NH3 desorption peak located at 100–500 °C is observed, suggesting the existence of weak (W, 100–200 °C), moderate (M, 200–350 °C) and strong acid sites (S, 350–550 °C) in the catalysts [24,46]. The acidity data of the catalysts is presented in Table 2. With the addition of tin, the total acid amount of the catalysts gradually decreases from 2057 μmol/g for ZrP to 1232 μmol/g for Zr0.4Sn0.6P, while the ratio of strong acid sites to the sum of weak and moderate acid sites (S/(W+M)) increases first, and then decreases. The total acid amount of Zr0.6Sn0.4P is 1515 μmol/g, and the value of S/(W+M) is 0.76. When the Zr element in the zirconium-tin phosphates is completely replaced by Sn element, the synthesized SnP shows the lowest total acid amount (1107 μmol/g) and the maximum value of S/(W+M) (1.22). Pyridine-adsorption FTIR spectra were employed to identify the types of acid sites in the zirconium-tin phosphates. As displayed in Fig. 4c, the adsorption peaks at 1447 cm−1 and 1545 cm−1 are caused by the pyridine adsorbed on Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, respectively [24,31]. Clearly, ZrP, SnP and the zirconium-tin phosphates all contain Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. The Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in these catalysts arise from hydroxyl group (P-OH) and metal sites (Zr(IV), Sn(IV)), respectively [26,36,40]. The adsorption peaks at 1447 cm−1 shifts gradually to higher wavenumbers (∼1553 cm−1) with the addition of tin in the zirconium-tin phosphates, indicating an increased Lewis acid strength for the zirconium-tin phosphates, which is well in line with the XPS analysis. The mole ratios of Lewis to Brønsted acid sites (L/B) in the catalysts are listed in Table 2. With the addition of tin, the L/B mole ratio increases first, and then decreases. Compared with ZrP, the Zr0.6Sn0.4P achieves a higher value of L/B (1.26), which is in good agreement with that of 31P MAS NMR analysis. With further increasing the addition of tin, the L/B mole ratio of Zr046Sn0.4P decreases to 0.99. However, the SnP catalyst exhibits the maximum L/B mole ratio of 1.68. Based on the NH3-TPD and Pyridine adsorption FTIR, it can be concluded that the total acid amount, acid strength distribution and acid site types of the zirconium-tin phosphates can be well controlled via the addition of different amounts of tin species. The temperature-programmed desorption of DMF/ethylene (DMF/C2H4-TPD) were conducted on the zirconium-tin phosphate catalysts to evaluate the effect of the addition of Sn on the adsorption of DMF and ethylene molecules. As shown in Fig. 5a, ZrP exhibits a small C2H4 desorption peaks centered at 90 °C, implying the presence of the weaker interaction between C2H4 molecules and the catalyst. Whereas, for SnP, no C2H4 desorption peak was observed under the present experimental conditions. Even if the desorption temperature was raised to 700 °C, no C2H4 desorption was detected as shown in Fig. S4. These results suggest that there may be no interaction between the C2H4 molecules and the Sn sites of the catalyst [42,47]. Because it is generally believed that ethylene was adsorbed on the catalyst surface via the interaction of π-electrons of CC band of ethylene molecules with coordinately unsaturated metal sites of catalysts [47]. Compared to ZrP and SnP, the C2H4 desorption peaks on the zirconium-tin phosphates shift to higher temperature and remarkably increase in intensity, indicating that the incorporation of Sn into the ZrP is beneficial to improving the C2H4 adsorption capability of the zirconium phosphates. This is probably caused by the decreased electron density of Zr and Sn species in the zirconium-tin phosphates, as the previous studies have found that the decrease in electron density for metal species can lead to an enhancement of the interaction between C2H4 molecule and metal species in the catalysts [23,42,47]. Among the catalysts, Zr0.6Sn0.4P shows the highest capability of C2H4 adsorption, followed by Zr0.5Sn0.5P and Zr0.4Sn0.6P, which can be attributed to the presence of more metal species with lower electron density in Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst. The TPD-DMF profiles in Fig. 4b reveals that the addition of Sn also enhances the adsorption capability of DMF, which could be due to the increase in the number of surface hydroxyl groups in the zirconium-tin phosphates as confirmed by XPS analysis [11]. 3.2 Catalytic activity The activity of the various catalysts for the preparation of PX from DMF and ethylene were investigated at 250 °C in 4 h ( Table 3). Firstly, a blank experiment was performed without any catalyst, and the results showed that DMF conversion did not occur under these conditions. In the presence of ZrP, 86% of DMF was converted, with a PX selectivity of 85.5%. With the addition of tin into ZrP, the DMF conversion decreases slowly from 86% to 79%, while the total acid content in these catalysts decreases greatly from 2057 to 1232 μmol/g (Table 2). When the Zr element in the zirconium phosphate was completely replaced by the Sn element, the synthesized SnP with the lowest total acid content (1107 μmol/g) exhibited the minimum DMF conversion of 68%. The result further confirms that the increase of total acid amount of the catalysts contributes to DMF conversion. In contrast, the product selectivity shows different trends with the addition of tin. As increasing the doping amount of tin, the selectivity of PX increases first and then decreases slightly. Upon increasing the mole fraction of tin up to 0.4, the PX selectivity increases from 85.5% for ZrP to 90.9% for Zr0.6Sn0.4P. Previous studies [20–22] have found that the lower proportion of strong acid sites (S/(W+M)) is beneficial to inhibiting the formation of byproducts and unknown oligomers. However, the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst with a higher S/(W+M) ratio (076) exhibits a better PX selectivity, which could be ascribed to its suitable L/B ratio (1.26) [21,24]. As shown in Scheme 1, the conversion of DMF and ethylene to PX contains two main reaction steps, including Diels-Alder reaction and the subsequent dehydration. For Zr0.6Sn0.4P, a high-content Lewis acid sites could efficiently promote the Diels-Alder reaction between DMF and ethylene to form cycloaddition intermediate (CH), then the CH undergoes quickly dehydration reaction to form PX in the presence of adjacent Brønsted acid sites. Although ZrP possesses a lower proportion of strong acid sites, the excessive Brønsted acid sites enhances the hydrolysis of DMF and the subsequent condenses intramolecular of HDO, as confirmed by the higher selectivity of CP and unknown byproducts. Especially for ZrP and Zr0.5Sn0.5P, both of them have the same proportion of strong acid sites, but the Zr0.5Sn0.5P with the higher L/B ratio exhibits a better PX selectivity, which further confirms that the synergistic effects between Lewis and Brønsted acid sites plays a vital role in the current catalytic system. With further increasing the mole fraction of tin to 0.6, the PX selectivity decreases slightly for the Zr0.4Sn0.6P catalyst, which could be attributed to the excessive Brønsted acid sites in the Zr0.4Sn0.6P catalyst. However, for SnP, the selectivity of PX decreases to 77.2%, and a high selectivity of CH, AP and unknown byproducts are observed in the Table 3, which could be caused by the overhigh proportion of strong acid sites and lower L/B mole ratio in the SnP catalyst. On the whole, as a good catalyst for the preparation of PX from DMF and ethylene, it is crucial to realize the subtle regulation for the acid strength and acid site types of catalysts. Eventually, the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst with an appropriate distribution of acid strength and L/B ratio exhibits a moderate catalytic activity and the highest PX selectivity. Moreover, we also examined the catalytic performance of the ZrP material modified by other metals i.e. Ce, Al and Ti. The results found that a DMF conversion of 87% and a PX selectivity of 86.4% were obtained over Zr0.6Ce0.4P, indicating that the incorporation of Ce into the ZrP has no remarkable promoting effect on the production of PX from DMF and ethylene. For Zr0.6Al0.4P, the DMF conversion was 89%, while the PX selectivity decreased to 75.7%, and the selectivity of CP and unknown byproducts increased to 3.7% and 14.5%, respectively. This may be due to the increase of strong Brønsted acid sites in the Zr0.6Al0.4P catalyst caused by the addition of Al into ZrP [49], which could help to enhance the hydrolysis of DMF and subsequent condensation, thereby greatly reducing the selectivity of PX. The Zr0.6Ti0.4P catalyst gave 85% DMF conversion and 87.4% PX selectivity, suggesting that the incorporation of Ti into ZrP can lead to a slight increase of PX selectivity. 3.3 Optimization of reaction conditions In order to further improve the conversion of DMF and obtain a higher yield of PX, Zr0.6Sn0.4P was selected as the catalyst to investigate the effects of reaction conditions on the conversion of DMF and ethylene. As shown in Fig. 6, as the reaction temperature rises from 230 to 260 °C, the conversion of DMF improves from 70% to 88%. Whereas, the selectivity of HDO and unknown byproducts decrease remarkably; while the CP and AP selectivity remains at lower values. The maximum PX selectivity of 91.2% is achieved at 260 °C. The results indicate that a higher reaction temperature helps to accelerate the Diels-Alder reaction and subsequent dehydration to produce PX [18]. However, when the reaction temperature is further improved to 270 °C, the conversion of DMF slightly rises, while the PX selectivity declines with the increase of unknown byproducts, indicating that high reaction temperature promotes side reactions [48]. Thus, the optimal reaction temperature is 260 °C for the current catalytic system. Fig. 6b shows that initial ethylene pressure has a large impact on the DMF conversion and product distribution. When ethylene pressure improves from 1 MPa to 4 MPa, DMF conversion and PX selectivity remarkably improves from 54% to 88%, and from 74.1% to 91.2%, respectively, which is likely caused by the fact that high ethylene pressure can enhance the Diels-Alder cycloaddition reaction rate, and then promotes the formation of PX [21,32]. As ethylene pressure continually rises, PX selectivity declines slightly, while the AP selectivity increases, indicating that the excessive ethylene promotes the alkylation reaction between PX and ethylene. Hence, the optimal ethylene pressure is 4 MPa. As presented in Fig. 6c, DMF conversion slowly goes up with increasing catalyst dosage. While, the PX selectivity reaches the highest value of 92.8% at a catalyst dosage of 2.5 wt% (based on the DMF mass), then decreases with further increasing the catalyst dosage. Hence, in the following tests, the catalyst dosage was fixed at 2.5 wt% of DMF. From the Fig. 6d, it is obvious that DMF conversion increases greatly from 59% to 96% with prolonging reaction time from 1 to 6 h. Within a 12 h reaction time, the DMF conversion, PX selectivity and PX yield reach up to 99%, 95.2% and 94.2%, respectively. In the light of the above experimental results, the optimum reaction conditions for the PX production are 2.5 wt% Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst dosage, 4 MPa ethylene, 260 °C for 12 h. By comparing the catalytic performance of Zr0.6Sn0.4P with other catalysts reported in the literature (Table S2), it was found that this catalyst exhibited better performance in converting DMF and ethylene to PX under moderate reaction conditions. As shown in Table S2, the catalytic conversion of DMF using Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst exhibits almost the highest PX productivity and yield. In addition, compared to most systems using other solid acid catalysts, the conversion of DMF and ethylene in this study was performed under milder reaction conditions with shorter reaction time and lower catalyst dosage. 3.4 Kinetic analysis To further gain insight into the superior catalytic performance of the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst, the kinetic experiments for the conversion of DMF and ethylene to PX over Zr0.6Sn0.4P were performed at 220–250 °C. A low catalyst dosage (0.0154 g, acid concentration ∼1 mM) was applied in the kinetic experiments to achieve a low DMF conversion and to obtain more accurate data. The kinetic plots of PX production on the catalyst are displayed in Fig. 7a. Clearly, the PX production has a well linear relationship with the reaction time. According to the data in Fig. 7a, the initial formation rate of PX (r 0) at various reaction temperatures was achieved. On the basis of reported studies [11,13,23,50], the formation rate of PX can be expressed as zero order kinetics models at lower acid site concentrations due to the use of a vast excessive ethylene and a constant amount of catalyst in the kinetic experiments. Therefore, the effect of acid site concentration on PX productivity on Zr0.6Sn0.4P was carried out. As presented in Fig S5, it is clear that the acid site concentration in the current reaction kinetics experiment is within the low acid site concentration range (< 2.9 mM). Hence, the Arrhenius diagram based on the linear relationship between lnr 0 and 1/T is displayed in Fig. 7b. As presented in Fig. 7b, the liner fitting curve fits well with the date points obtained in the experiments. The value of apparent activation energy (Ea) of Zr0.6Sn0.4P is 39 kJ·mol−1, much smaller than 45.1 kJ·mol−1 over HY zeolite [11], 48.9 kJ·mol−1 over H-BEA zeolite [50] and 68.0 kJ·mol−1 over Zr-Beta zeolite [51]. This result indicates that, compared to the catalysts reported above, a large number of active sites with lower reaction barriers were achieved on the surface of Zr0.6Sn0.4P. Obviously, the active sites with lower reaction barrier contributes to improve the reaction rate for the conversion of DMF and ethylene to PX [25], thereby resulting in a higher catalytic activity for Zr0.6Sn0.4P in PX production from DMF and ethylene than other solid acid catalysts. The catalytic performance of Zr0.6Sn0.4P and the reported catalysts in the literatures for the conversion of DMF and ethylene to PX is presented in Table S2. From the Table S2, it can be clearly seen that a higher PX production rate and PX yield were achieved on the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst with a shorter reaction time and a lower catalyst usage than other solid acid catalysts. 3.5 Catalyst stability The catalyst stability is of great significance for practical application, thus the recyclability of the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst was explored in the conversion of DMF and ethylene to PX. As displayed in Fig. 8a, after reaction at 250 °C for 2 h the reaction was stopped and the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst was removed by filtration from the reaction mixture. Then, the resulting filtrate was re-added into the autoclave, followed by further reaction for 10 h under the same reaction conditions. It is evident that the conversion of DMF remained unchanged after removing the catalyst. Moreover, none of Zr, Sn and P elements were detected in the filtrate by ICP-OES analysis, confirming that no catalyst leaching occurred and the reaction was indeed heterogeneous. In recycling test, the used catalyst was washed with water and ethanol, dried at 100 °C overnight, and then subjected to the next run. As displayed in Fig. 8b, the DMF conversion gradually decreases from 90% to 78% after the fourth use, while the PX selectivity decreases relatively small. To investigate the reasons for the decrease in catalytic activity, FT-IR and TG analyses were conducted using the fresh and used catalyst. FT-IR spectra in Fig. S6a confirmed that some carbonaceous species were adsorbed on the surface of the used catalyst. TG curves in Fig. S6b exhibits a significant weight loss of Zr0.6Sn0.4P from 350 to 600 °C, which can be attributed to the burning of organic compounds deposited on the catalyst surface. Therefore, the main factor causing the decrease in catalytic activity is the formation of carbon deposits. In the subsequent runs, the used catalyst was washed with water and ethanol, dried at 100 °C overnight, and finally regenerated by calcination at 500 °C for 4 h. As can be seen from the Fig. 8b, the regenerated catalyst gave a DMF conversion of 89% and a PX selectivity of 93.1% after six consecutive reaction cycles, which are comparable to that of the fresh catalyst. These results indicates that the used Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst could be easily regenerated by calcination, and showed an excellent catalytic stability. Subsequently, the fresh and regenerated Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst (after the sixth runs) were characterized by various techniques. FT-IR spectra in Fig. S6a and XRD patterns in Fig. S6c reveal no significant changes between the fresh and regenerated Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalysts, implying that the structure of the catalyst is not altered during the regeneration. N2 physical adsorption and NH3-TPD profiles in Fig. S6d-e show that compared with fresh catalysts, the specific surface area and acidic density of the regenerated catalyst declines slightly from 302.1 m2/g and 1515 μmol/g to 296.7 m2/g and 1456 μmol/g, respectively. These results demonstrate that the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst has stable structure and surface properties. 3.6 Surface reaction mechanism To gain further insight into the adsorption and reaction of DMF and ethylene molecules on the catalyst surface, the temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) of DMF and ethylene on the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst was investigated. As shown in Fig. 9a-b, the partial adsorbed DMF and ethylene molecules on the catalyst surface were desorbed during the temperature-programmed process. The desorption peaks of DMF are quite similar whether DMF or ethylene was firstly introduced onto the catalyst surface (Fig. 9a), and the DMF desorption peaks in TPSR are also close with the result of TPD-DMF on Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst as shown in Fig. 5a. The desorption of ethylene in the Fig. 9b also exhibit the similar phenomenon. These results suggest that the DMF and ethylene molecules are adsorbed on the different active sites on catalysts surface and does not affect each other. Similar results were also observed during in-situ FT-IR adsorption of DMF and ethylene on the ZrP-2.5 catalyst in our previous study [52]. The in-situ FT-IR characterization of the ZrP-2.5 catalyst confirmed the presence of interaction between the oxygen atoms of DMF and P-OH, and the coordinately unsaturated Zr(IV) in ZrP-2.5 interacted with the π - electrons of the ethylene CC bond. Thereby, it can be concluded that, for the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst, the DMF molecules should be adsorbed on the catalyst surface via the interaction between P-OH in catalyst and oxygen atom of furan; while the ethylene molecules should be adsorbed on the catalyst surface via the interaction between the π-electrons of ethylene CC bond and metal sites of catalyst. Furthermore, TPSR-DMF-C2H4 and TPSR-C2H4-DMF profiles in the Fig. 9c-d reveal that CH intermediate and a small amount of PX and HDO were generated during the temperature-programmed process, indicating that the adsorbed DMF and ethylene molecules on the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst surface all undergo the Diels-Alder and dehydration reaction, regardless of the order of introduction of DMF and ethylene. The results further confirm that DMF and ethylene molecule should be adsorbed on the different active sites of the catalyst because the product PX can be formed whether the DMF or ethylene was firstly introduced onto the catalyst surface. According to the preceding results and the previously reported studies on the reaction of DMF and ethylene [11,42,52–54], a reasonable reaction mechanism for the reaction of DMF and ethylene in the presence of Zr0.6Sn0.4P was proposed ( Scheme 2). In the Diels-Alder reaction step, DMF molecules are firstly adsorbed and activated on the catalyst surface via the interaction between furan oxygen of DMF and P-OH in the catalyst to form complex, and then the complex formed a six-membered ring transition state (a0) with the adjacent CC of ethylene adsorbed on the coordinately unsaturated metal sites. Afterwards, a stable cycloadduct intermediate (a1) is quickly produced through the electron rearrangement of the six-membered ring species. Therefore, the active sites P-OH (Brønsted acid sites) and metal sites (Lewis acids sites) play a vital role for the adsorption and activation of DMF and ethylene molecule. The enhanced DMF and ethylene adsorption on the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst is beneficial to enriching a higher concentration DMF and ethylene on the catalyst surface, and then promoting the Diels-Alder reaction to produce more cycloadduct intermediate. Subsequently, the produced cycloadduct intermediate undergoes the dehydration reaction to generate PX and equal molecule of H2O in the presence of either Brønsted or Lewis acid sites. The dehydration reaction step mainly includes three elementary reactions: (1) C4-Of (furan oxygen) bond cleavage, (2) 1st proton transfer and (3) 2nd proton transfer. By combining the present experiment results and previous studies [18,20,24,52], it can be concluded that the Brønsted acid sites is more active for the dehydration reaction than Lewis acid sites. However, the excessive Brønsted acid sites also enhance the hydrolysis of DMF and subsequent condensation of HDO, which leads to a reduction of the PX selectivity, especially for the Brønsted acid sites with high acid strength. In conclusion, catalysts with appropriate Brønsted/Lewis acid site ratio and acid strength distribution are very important for the efficient and highly selective production of PX from DMF and ethylene. 4 Conclusion In this study, a series of zirconium-tin phosphate solid acids were prepared via a hydrothermal method. These catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic activity and stability for the conversion of DMF and ethylene to PX. With Zr0.6Sn0.4P as the catalyst, 99% DMF conversion, 95.2% PX selectivity and 94.2% PX yield were achieved at 260 °C for 12 h with 4 MPa ethylene and 2.5 wt% catalyst dosage (based on the DMF mass). Compared with other reported solid acid catalyst, the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst achieved a higher PX yield in a shorter reaction time. The addition of Sn adjusted the acid properties of the catalyst and enhanced the adsorption of reactant molecules, which are beneficial to the generation of PX. Thus, this study provides a stable and simple solid acid catalyst for the efficient and highly selective production of PX from biobased DMF and ethylene, which has a good potential for practical applications. coredata.dc:description: Efficient production of renewable p-xylene (PX) from bio-based 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) and ethylene is challenging. Herein, novel nanoflake-like zirconium-tin phosphate catalysts were synthesized, and their catalytic performance was evaluated in the conversion of DMF and ethylene to PX. The DMF conversion, PX selectivity and PX yield reached up to 99%, 95.2% and 94.2%, respectively over Zr0.6Sn0.4P under relatively mild conditions. The PX productivity was 61.1 mmolPX·gcat −1·h−1, which is better than that of previously reported catalysts. By combining characterization with activity test, it was found that enhanced DMF and ethylene adsorption is beneficial to promoting the reaction between DMF and ethylene. Precise regulation of acid sites is crucial for inhibiting the occurrence of side reactions and improving the selectivity of PX. The kinetic analysis revealed that Zr0.6Sn0.4P had a relatively low apparent activation energy (39 kJ·mol−1) for this reaction than previously reported catalysts. In addition, the Zr0.6Sn0.4P catalyst exhibited an excellent reusability.
coredata.dc:title: Zirconium-tin phosphate as an efficient catalyst for renewable p-xylene synthesis from biobased 2,5-dimethylfuran and ethylene
